The highly motile state appears during post-exponential growth when resources diminish further (stationary phase), the organism changes strategy: growth slows, motility decreases (a huge energy savings), and the synthesis of adhesins such as curli pili increases.
Low c-di-GMP concentration favors motility and scavenging.
The transition can be seen clearly in batch cultures.
High Lower levels of c-di-GMP in exponential phase favor motility and the search for food.
Another important second messenger is cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP) (Fig. 10.29), which is one key to timing biofilm formation.
Cyclic di-GMP is a ubiq■ second messenger in bacteria and is not found in production by Salmonella requires c-di-GMP.

Thus, highly motile cells are made in post-exponenTime tial phase while sessile, adherent cells able to produce biofilms are produced in stationary that c-di-GMP is required for Salmonella to make biofilms.
